reasoning: The critique targets a real inferential step in Sec. 3.3: the move from “bounded over universe-as-a-whole” to “practically linear, hence fussy,” which the essay motivates partly via a very large universe and likely many alien civilizations making humanity’s marginal contribution tiny. If that empirical/cosmological setup fails, the ‘locally linear’ argument for that subclass of bounded views is weakened, which moderately matters to the essay’s broader claim that most plausible views are fussy (though the essay also has independent routes to fussiness: unbounded-linear views, high-bound difference-making views being near-linear, and low-bound separate-aggregation views being fussy via ‘tiny bads’). The objection is fairly strong as a conditional vulnerability/parameter-sensitivity point, but it likely doesn’t “flip” the overall conclusion by itself because (i) the essay can replace “aliens” with the weaker premise “we are far from saturation given enormous attainable value,” and (ii) even if universe-as-a-whole bounded views aren’t near-linear, other considered bounded views can still be fussy. The critique is mostly correct, clearly stated, focused on one issue, and contains little fluff.
title: The linearity result relies on speculative “many aliens” assumptions about negligible marginal impact
